courses.THEA 7 — The Arts Dean's Lecture Series:
Course: THEA 7 — The Arts Dean's Lecture Series on the Art of Change with Lyle Troxell of Netflix
Credits: 2
Description: Course features a distinguished roster of guest speakers of arts practitioners and educators who provide illuminating insights and personal stories on the artistic character that can shape a creative life dedicated to social change. Speakers cover a lively range of topics, ranging from the importance of habits of heart and mind that can transform "some thing" into something "original" to the ways the arts create productive change. Taught by Lyle Troxell, host of the WeAreNetflix Podcast. (Formerly Arts Dean's Lecture Series on Creative Entrepreneurship.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 8 — Introduction to Iranian Theatre:
Course: THEA 8 — Introduction to Iranian Theatre
Credits: 2
Description: Introduces Iranian theater covering Ta'zieh religious performance, Ruhuzi improvised drama, Naghali storytelling, and modern efforts in national and diasporic theaters fusing indigenous and western styles. No prior knowledge of Iran is required and readings are in English.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 10 — Introduction to Theater Design:
Course: THEA 10 — Introduction to Theater Design and Technology
Credits: 5
Description: Addresses imagination and creativity. Using the framework of theater production, students explore the process of translating a script into a performance. Topics include visual literacy, creative problem solving, establishing effective working teams, tear sheets, storyboarding, drawing, sound and color theory. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-division design courses.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 12 — Stage Management:
Course: THEA 12 — Stage Management
Credits: 5
Description: Designed to acquaint students with the complexities of staging productions from the audition process to final performance. Directing, lighting, scenic production, sound, cueing, and personnel management are aspects that will be touched upon in class.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 14 — Drawing:
Course: THEA 14 — Drawing
Credits: 5
Description: A fundamental course in drawing from still life, the figure, and in the landscape. The approach is from the tonal and volumetric aspects of the object. Color is introduced as the course progresses. Instruction fashioned to the individual needs of the student. The inexperienced are welcomed as well as the experienced.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 15 — Special Topics in Textiles:
Course: THEA 15 — Special Topics in Textiles
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces varied techniques in textile manipulation to create scenic and costume-design properties including drapery, upholstery, masks, bags, and millinery. Students learn basic sewing and surface-design methods, such as knitting, screen-printing, painting/dyeing, and distressing.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 17 — Costume Construction:
Course: THEA 17 — Costume Construction
Credits: 5
Description: Explores different aspects of costume construction, including draping, basic sewing, flat patterning techniques, proper protocols for measurements and fittings, dyeing, and costume crafting. The class activities are a mixture of lectures, demonstrations, and project-based learning. Students work in a lab setting and learn proper costume shop etiquette regarding shared spaces, organization, and cleanliness.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 18 — Drafting for Theatrical Produc:
Course: THEA 18 — Drafting for Theatrical Production
Credits: 5
Description: An examination of the fundamentals of drafting scale drawings for production, including floor plans, elevations, sections, working drawings, dimensions, layout, and lettering. Students learn isometric drawing, perspective, and rendering techniques.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 18C — Drafting-Computer Aided:
Course: THEA 18C — Drafting-Computer Aided
Credits: 5
Description: In-depth exploration of designing for theater using computer-aided drafting in the Vectorworks Design Suite and Renderworks. Topics include: the user interface, ground plan, section and detail views, paper space vs. working space, tool palettes, USITT drafting standards, layers, line weights, objects, classes, library annotations, importing rasters, and 3D modeling. Students required to do weekly projects such as ground plans, lighting plots, perspectives, and detail drawings, as well as turn in a major final project, and complete a mid-term, final, and quizzes.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 19 — Design Studio: Lighting Studio:
Course: THEA 19 — Design Studio: Lighting Studio A
Credits: 5
Description: An introduction to the theory and practice of lighting design with attention to the practical skills and creative approaches to lighting performance pieces; the technical side of lighting design via demonstrations, lectures, and labs. Students complete projects evolving and executing concepts for lighting chosen pieces.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 .
courses.THEA 20 — Introductory Studies in Acting:
Course: THEA 20 — Introductory Studies in Acting
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to basic acting skills and the problems of performance. Concentrates on expanding a range of expression and ability to respond to and analyze dramatic text. Designed for students with little or no experience in acting.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 21 — Acting Studio I: Psychological:
Course: THEA 21 — Acting Studio I: Psychological Realism
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the fundamentals from the work of Konstantin Stanislavski as developed at the Moscow Art Theater to the works of his and our contemporary playwrights. Specifically, students apply those techniques of action, physical score, given circumstances, subtext, interior monologue, goals, and objectives, throughline, superobjective, and emotional recall to works of Henrik Ibsen, Anton Chekov, and relevant American realists, such as Sam Shepard, August Wilson, etc. Designed for students focused on acting as an academic or professional discipline. Admission by audition at first class meeting.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 22 — Indonesian Dance and Drama:
Course: THEA 22 — Indonesian Dance and Drama
Credits: 5
Description: Students learn the basic movement repertoire of the specific characters of the Indonesian dance-drama/puppetry tradition over the quarter with explication of how these types operate in their own cultural context. Course culminates in an open showing of scene work.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 23 — Voice for the Actor:
Course: THEA 23 — Voice for the Actor
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces using the spoken voice effectively and powerfully on stage and off. Physical release, alignment, breath, resonance, and articulation are explored. Students gain an understanding of how the voice relates to the self, the body, and breath and become more aware of tensions and habits that may impede vocal and speech use.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 24 — Movement for Performers:
Course: THEA 24 — Movement for Performers
Credits: 5
Description: Students develop awareness and extension of personal movement repertoire through observation, movement experience, and exploration.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 25 — Understanding Shakespeare:
Course: THEA 25 — Understanding Shakespeare
Credits: 5
Description: Emphasizes key theoretical and practical modes of dramaturgy in order to research, analyze, and interpret the dramatic works and performances of Shakespeare within historical and contemporary contexts.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 30 — Introduction to Dance Theory a:
Course: THEA 30 — Introduction to Dance Theory and Technique
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive instruction in developing the dancer's mind/body, with introduction to movement theory and practice.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 31A — Dance Studio I: Asian or Asia:
Course: THEA 31A — Dance Studio I: Asian or Asian Diasporic Practice
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces Asian or Asian diasporic dance practice through physical training and theoretical engagement. Focuses on basic techniques of performance practice and critical engagement with aesthetic, cultural, and/or historical context.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 31B — Dance Studio I: Ballet:
Course: THEA 31B — Dance Studio I: Ballet
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces classical ballet as a form of ethnic dance. Focus on combining basic training in ballet technique with academic studies to achieve a synthesis in the understanding of dance as a performing arts practice in diverse socio-cultural and historical contexts. Emphasis on simple phrasing and articulation into more complex material requiring richer dynamic range. Attention to the anatomical principles that governs ballet mechanics.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 31C — Dance Studio I: Contemporary:
Course: THEA 31C — Dance Studio I: Contemporary Dance Theory and Technique
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive instruction in contemporary dance technique. Combining movement theory and practice, students will develop basic knowledge of anatomical function (somatics) and a foundational embodiment of contemporary dance technique.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 31E — The Dance Experience:
Course: THEA 31E — The Dance Experience
Credits: 2
Description: Introduction to contemporary dance theory and practice. Focus on basic dance technique, range of styles, and aesthetic points of view of historically significant contemporary dance choreographers in America and worldwide.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 31L — Dance Studio I: Introduction:
Course: THEA 31L — Dance Studio I: Introduction to Latin American Social Dances
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces movement fundamentals and histories of two Afro-Latin social dances: samba from Brazil, and salsa from Cuba. Students learn about their common Afro-Indigenous roots and stylistic evolutions, as well as key threads that connect a wide range of people and practices across the Latin Diasporaâculturally, musically, physically, and spiritually. Course examines the complex origins and how they arose out of histories of persecution, enslavement, migration, and a deep desire to hold onto tradition and celebrate life in the face of great injustice. Includes attendance at off-campus community dance events, plus weekly movement practice and lectures in class, reading and writing assignments, and keeping a journal that reflects on their ongoing experience.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 31M — Introduction to Aikido:
Course: THEA 31M — Introduction to Aikido
Credits: 5
Description: Provides students with an introduction to the practice of Aikido, a contemporary Japanese martial art founded in the mid-20th century by Morihei Ueshiba (O-Sensei). Essentially nonviolent and noncompetitive, Aikido aims to achieve harmony with others, the environment, and oneself. Students who complete this course will be able to perform basic Aikido techniques, demonstrate their understanding of the Japanese terminology used in class, and apply the philosophies outlined to the physical practice of the form.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 33C — Dance Studio I:
Course: THEA 33C — Dance Studio I
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive instruction in developing the dancer's physical instrument. Intended for students who have a previous fundamental knowledge of the basics of classic dance, combined with movement theory.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 36 — Introduction to Dance Making:
Course: THEA 36 — Introduction to Dance Making
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces dance improvisation and choreographic practice. Observation and recognition of personal movement patterns and discovering new sources for creative material. (Formerly offered as Introduction to Dance Composition.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 37 — African Dance:
Course: THEA 37 — African Dance
Credits: 5
Description: A griot (musician-entertainer from western Africa) from Burkina Faso teaches The African Journey, which emphasizes dance as combined in Africa, including singing, history, oral tradition, and storytelling.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 38 — Dance on Film:
Course: THEA 38 — Dance on Film
Credits: 2
Description: Introduces dance on film, examining such topics as narrative storytelling in dance films (documentary and fiction); cinematic strategies for representing the kinesthetic; and dance film as a unique and distinct art form.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 40 — Introduction to Directing:
Course: THEA 40 — Introduction to Directing
Credits: 5
Description: An overview of the analytical and creative processes that inform the director's work. Close examination of texts, concepts, and selected directors and directorial choices.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 41 — Fundamentals of Directing:
Course: THEA 41 — Fundamentals of Directing
Credits: 5
Description: An experience designed to develop an active and creative vision leading to a concept that takes an audience on a memorable journey with lives that are created on the stage. Students direct a monologue, a dual scene, and a final project which represents the collaborative nature of the art of directing. Topics include blocking techniques, history of directing, how to work with designers, rehearsal techniques, and strategies for actor coaching.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 50 — Fundamentals of Theater Produc:
Course: THEA 50 — Fundamentals of Theater Production
Credits: 2
Description: Work is on various aspects of theatrical production, including scenery, lighting, costumes, sound, stage management, and video documentation. Satisfies the department's technical experience requirement.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 52 — Basic Stagecraft:
Course: THEA 52 — Basic Stagecraft
Credits: 5
Description: Provides introduction to technical theater and basic stagecraft. Course examines two-dimensional and three-dimensional scenery, scenic engineering, the physical theater, stage and scene shop equipment, project organization and process, technical theater graphics, materials, and theatrical construction techniques.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 .
courses.THEA 55A — Workshop in Performance: Barn:
Course: THEA 55A — Workshop in Performance: Barnstorm
Credits: 5
Description: Process-oriented investigation of practical theater production by working in and on productions in the Barnstorm season. Requires a total of 150 hours working backstage or onstage. Admission by audition at first class meeting; see department office for more information.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 55B — Workshop in Performance: Barn:
Course: THEA 55B — Workshop in Performance: Barnstorm Lab
Credits: 2
Description: Process-oriented investigation of practical theater production by working in and on productions in the Barnstorm season. Requires a total of 50 hours working backstage or onstage. Admission by audition at first class meeting; see department office for more information.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 56D — Rainbow Theater Cultural Stud:
Course: THEA 56D — Rainbow Theater Cultural Studies
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to multicultural theater and multicultural plays that aims to bring cultural awareness to all students interested in theater discipline. Students are required to read and critically analyze contemporary plays of color with emphasis on race and culture in contemporary American society. (Formerly OAKS 80H.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 56R — Rainbow Theater: An Introduct:
Course: THEA 56R — Rainbow Theater: An Introduction to Multicultural Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to Asian American, Chicano/Latino, and African American plays through reading of major authors, discussion of social and historical context of their work, and development of a production of a one-act play from each cultural group. In-depth examination of key historical context of these three cultural groups. Video presentations followed by class discussion. Enrollment by audition. (Formerly offered solely as STEV 80H. Now offered as both THEA 56R and STEV 80H, with THEA 56R the primary offering and STEV 80H the crosslisted offering.)
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 61A — Ancient and Medieval Drama:
Course: THEA 61A — Ancient and Medieval Drama
Credits: 5
Description: Ancient enmities; horrific acts of parricide; monumental errors; suffering and contrition. This course examines the enormous appeal of the ancient Greek tragic and comic visions from their inception through their enthusiastic adaptation by the Romans and on into the Middle Ages. For comparison purposes, Greek and Roman dramas are studied back-to-back with the contemporary non-Western dramatic forms of Noh and ancient Sanskrit drama.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 61B — Drama from the Renaissance to:
Course: THEA 61B — Drama from the Renaissance to the Modern Age
Credits: 5
Description: Examines major trends in European drama from the rediscovery of ancient Greek and Roman drama in the early 17th century to the late 19th century. These trends include neo-classical drama, the rise of middle-class drama, social realism, romanticism, early naturalism, and the well-made play. These trends are compared with the parallel developments of the non-Western forms of Japanese Kabuki and Javanese Wayang.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 61C — The Birth of the Modern: Dram:
Course: THEA 61C — The Birth of the Modern: Drama and Performance After the Renaissance
Credits: 5
Description: Examines dramatic and theatrical works that sprang into being in the wake of the European Renaissance. Follows the ways modern artists have dramatized their questions, struggles, beliefs, and despair in the face of world wars, cultural fragmentation, unprecedented prosperity, and new technologies.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 64 — Shakespeare and Adaptation in:
Course: THEA 64 — Shakespeare and Adaptation in Text and Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Juxtaposes Shakespeare's plays with sources Shakespeare may have adapted and adaptations that his works, in turn, have spawned. Explores Renaissance stage and printing practices and the processes of adapting for page and stage.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80A — Introduction to African Ameri:
Course: THEA 80A — Introduction to African American Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys African American theater from late-19th-century to contemporary 21st-century playwrights and examines dramatic narratives to trace creation, evolution, and development of African American cultural identity formation in American theater.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80B — Rock 'n' Roll Design:
Course: THEA 80B — Rock 'n' Roll Design
Credits: 5
Description: Examination of the genesis, history, and development of technical theater practices used in large arena rock shows. Topics will include the development of rigging practices used in arenas, touring logistics, lighting instrumentation and aesthetics of rock shows, and the nature, practice, and approach of sound in these venues.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80C — Monsters:
Course: THEA 80C — Monsters
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the operation of monsters in plays from Ancient Greece to today, inquiring as to why these powerful cultural tools for the expression of social tension show no sign of diminishing despite our ostensible advance into scientific rationalism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80D — Commercial Design 1900 to Pre:
Course: THEA 80D — Commercial Design 1900 to Present
Credits: 5
Description: History of 20th-century commercial design for the theater through the eyes of the Western consumer.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80H — Hamlet Conundrums:
Course: THEA 80H — Hamlet Conundrums
Credits: 5
Description: Offered online, the course explores major issues of interpretation of Shakespeare's classic play, which has occupied the minds of audiences, directors, designers, performers, and critics during its 400-year history. In doing this, it offers a sense of history of people's preoccupations with and thoughts about the play. Students taking this class are expected to complete the course during the quarter for which they are enrolled. All students enrolled in this course should visit elsinore.ucsc.edu and write to elsinore@ucsc.edu.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80K — Shakespeare 4every1:
Course: THEA 80K — Shakespeare 4every1
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces all students, regardless of experience, to the plays and theater of Shakespeare, and directly addresses linked relevance to contemporary 21st century American culture.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80L — Muppet Magic: Jim Henson's Ar:
Course: THEA 80L — Muppet Magic: Jim Henson's Art
Credits: 5
Description: The artistic and social impact of the Muppets on American puppetry, children's television, and Hollywood film is explored through viewings, guest lectures, and analysis. Henson's legacy in artistic innovation, mainstreaming of puppet theater for adult audiences, and establishment of puppetry in media and marketing are also explored.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80M — Chicano/a Teatro:
Course: THEA 80M — Chicano/a Teatro
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to Teatro Chicano/a with examination of how cultural diversity plays a role in theater. Through lectures, films, and workshop exercises, reflect upon the process of Teatro Chicano. Students write their own acts, improvise, and perform in class.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80N — Walt Disney:
Course: THEA 80N — Walt Disney
Credits: 5
Description: An examination of Walt Disney's creation of the American vision of family entertainment. Particular attention will be paid to the classic animated feature films of Walt Disney and to the way this Disney invention has been preserved and developed since his death. We will also look at the live action films, theme parks, and other Disney creations.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80P — Pixar - Story Matters:
Course: THEA 80P — Pixar - Story Matters
Credits: 5
Description: Emphasizes script development by exploring dramatic writings from ancient to contemporary theater, then focusing on Pixar screenplays with their universal themes and compelling characters. Film analysis of Pixar movies delves into animation history, fairytale, psychology, and popular culture.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80Q — Introduction to Queer Theater:
Course: THEA 80Q — Introduction to Queer Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the history of the queer perspective in dramatic literature, from the Greeks to Marlowe and Shakespeare through the calcification of homosexuality in the era of Freud, then traces theater stewardship by gay and lesbian artists from within the closet and without.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80R — Bollywood Dance and Culture i:
Course: THEA 80R — Bollywood Dance and Culture in India and Indian Diaspora
Credits: 5
Description: Bollywood is the largest film industry in the world. Students learn several fundamental footsteps, eye, hand and body movements, to perform Bollywood dance. They also learn various traditions of Indian classical, folk, and Bollywood dance terms.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 80S — Theater Arts Education and th:
Course: THEA 80S — Theater Arts Education and the Community
Credits: 5
Description: This course is designed to develop ways in which we can direct our interest in the arts into concrete and successful community projects. Although the emphasis will be on developing skills to work within K-12 classrooms, other community projects will be discussed and designed.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80T — Flashmob! Mass Performance in:
Course: THEA 80T — Flashmob! Mass Performance in the Information Age
Credits: 5
Description: Flashmobs represent a new social configuration using information technology. Course covers the history of experiments in art and technology and the role of mass performance in society. Students consider the socio-cultural ramifications of flashmobs and participate in them.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80U — Everybody Dance Now!:
Course: THEA 80U — Everybody Dance Now!
Credits: 5
Description: Examines dance as a primary mode of human communication and expression. Through readings and the viewing of recorded and live performances, students compare and contrast dance traditions of the world.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 80V — The Circus in American Cultur:
Course: THEA 80V — The Circus in American Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Circus arts from their shamanic roots to contemporary practice will be analyzed in a historical, aesthetic, and creative dimension. Lecture, discussion, and demonstrations will explore the theory and practice of American circus arts. In section, students will explore basic circus skills from clowning to tumbling to exhibition of freaks.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80X — The Performance of Story in T:
Course: THEA 80X — The Performance of Story in Theater and Film
Credits: 5
Description: An examination of the theory and practice of theater and film, comparing and contrasting works that have been adapted from one genre to another. Lecture, film and video viewing and discussion of materialist, psychoanalytic, and feminist approaches will be shared.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80Y — American Musical Theater:
Course: THEA 80Y — American Musical Theater
Credits: 5
Description: The history of American musical theater, from its roots to today, is studied through scripts, scores, and film. Major composers and lyricists' work is shown, discussed, and analyzed.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 80Z — Indian Dance:
Course: THEA 80Z — Indian Dance
Credits: 5
Description: Study of Indian classical dance through embodied training and theoretical engagement. Training in the foundational elements of abstract rhythmic dance, including drum syllables and associated steps, and introduction to abhinaya (storytelling).
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 99 — Tutorial:
Course: THEA 99 — Tutorial
Credits: 5
Description: Students must file their petitions for this course with the department office by the end of the fifth day of instruction in the quarter in which they would like to take the tutorial. Prerequisite(s): petition required, approved by instructor and department.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 100A — Asian Theater/Dance and Glob:
Course: THEA 100A — Asian Theater/Dance and Global Impacts
Credits: 5
Description: Overview of selected theater/dance performance genres of India, Indonesia, China, Korea, and Japan with attention to how cultural, political, and social flows have impacted contemporary performance in Asia and beyond. Lectures supplemented by workshops.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 100B — Black Theater USA:
Course: THEA 100B — Black Theater USA
Credits: 5
Description: Spanning slavery, emancipation, reconstruction, the great depression, civil rights, and the black power/black arts movements, course explores African American drama from literary, historical, and biographical perspectives in lecture/discussions, film excerpts, dramatizations, and visits from award-winning guests.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 100C — Courts, Courtesans, Shamans,:
Course: THEA 100C — Courts, Courtesans, Shamans, and Clowns: Asian Drama
Credits: 5
Description: Asian court and popular performance are traced. Sanskrit drama is contrasted with Indian epic recitation, medium, and courtesan dance. Gender specialization is noted in Indonesian courts using Indian and local legends in dance, mask/puppetry, and clowning. Buddhist and Confucian impulses in Chinese theater and early Korean and Japanese mask and puppetry are introduced. Students are evaluated on participation, tests, writing, and a performance project.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 100W — Black/African Diasporic Worl:
Course: THEA 100W — Black/African Diasporic World Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Examines major black African diasporic playwrights and theater. Focuses on the historical, cultural, and literary contexts that gave rise to the works of dramatists such as Ama Ata Aidoo, Derek Walcott, Wole Soyinke, Aime Cesaire, Debbie Green Tucker, and Paul Boakye.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 103 — Design Concept Development:
Course: THEA 103 — Design Concept Development
Credits: 5
Description: Students develop an advanced design project related to theatrical production, apparel or housewares, marketing collateral, packaging or product development, or any related fields. Students address research and development, materials sourcing, budgeting, fabrication, and portfolio-quality presentation materials. Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 ; or two courses from ART 10D , ART 10E , and ART 10F . Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. THEA 106 is recommended as preparation.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 104 — Multimedia Authoring:
Course: THEA 104 — Multimedia Authoring
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces students to basic tools for the creation of multimedia digital projects. Special attention is given to the integration of video, sound, graphics, text and virtual reality and to the creation and execution of strategies for interaction between users and the projects themselves. With this in mind, students design and create computer puzzles and games.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 106 — Digital Illustration:
Course: THEA 106 — Digital Illustration
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces tools and techniques for creating digital costume renderings and theatrical design illustrations using Procreate for iPad and the Adobe Creative applications. Explores a range of uses for digital renderings, including tools for design and communication.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to declared or proposed majors in art, games and playable media, creative technologies, film and digital media, or theater arts; or minors in dance, film and digital media, or theater arts.
courses.THEA 108 — Theater and Interaction Desig:
Course: THEA 108 — Theater and Interaction Design
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates interactive media including computer games, virtual reality, and participatory theater to inform design practice. Examines Aristotle's Poetics with some modernist excursions. Also examines the various values embedded in works--artistic, civic, spiritual, and political.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to juniors and seniors.
courses.THEA 113 — The History of Design for The:
Course: THEA 113 — The History of Design for Theater
Credits: 5
Description: The development of scenic design from the Greek period to the present. Concentration is on the changing styles of set design in relation to the changing attitudes toward dramatic literature, art, and theater architecture.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 114 — Sound Design and Engineering:
Course: THEA 114 — Sound Design and Engineering for the Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Mixing theory with practice, this course covers everything from script analysis and sound-design paperwork to how to use the software and hardware needed to bring a sound design to reality.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 .
courses.THEA 115A — Design Studio: Scenic Design:
Course: THEA 115A — Design Studio: Scenic Design
Credits: 5
Description: Advanced work in principles and theory of scenic design.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 .
courses.THEA 115B — Design Studio: Scenic Design:
Course: THEA 115B — Design Studio: Scenic Design B
Credits: 5
Description: Advanced theory and practice of theatrical set design.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 115.
courses.THEA 116A — History of Clothing and Cost:
Course: THEA 116A — History of Clothing and Costume
Credits: 5
Description: Survey of clothing and theatrical costumes; emphasis on dress of the audience and actor in historical periods of theatrical activity.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 117 — Design Studio: Costume:
Course: THEA 117 — Design Studio: Costume
Credits: 5
Description: Explores different aspects of the costume design process. Through projects and exercises, students develop a general view of various aspects of costume designers' work and gain a broader and more informed understanding of the costume designer's methods, techniques, and tools.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 117A — Advanced Costume Constructio:
Course: THEA 117A — Advanced Costume Construction
Credits: 5
Description: Advanced principles in costume construction, including tailoring, advanced pattern drafting, and draping techniques. Focuses on translating modern techniques into historical garment construction. Teaches how to study artifacts and do primary research to unlock the past.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): course 17.
courses.THEA 118 — Design Studio: Scene Painting:
Course: THEA 118 — Design Studio: Scene Painting
Credits: 5
Description: Emphasis on techniques used in painting scenery for the theater.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 10 .
courses.THEA 119 — Design Studio: Lighting Studi:
Course: THEA 119 — Design Studio: Lighting Studio B
Credits: 5
Description: The theory and practice of lighting design with emphasis on practical application. Light plots, electricity, optics, design, and manipulation of lighting for the theater and related performance events are investigated. The student explores mechanics and aesthetics with hands-on experience.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 19 .
courses.THEA 120 — Voice and Movement for Perfor:
Course: THEA 120 — Voice and Movement for Performers
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive work on the voice and body involving breathing, relaxation, and an understanding of anatomy as it pertains to voice and movement. Awareness and extension of personal vocal and movement repertoire through observation, experience, and exploration. Active preparation for performance (emphasizing Shakespeare) with work on phonetics and scansion and integration of physical technique.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 121 — Acting Studio II: Shakespeare:
Course: THEA 121 — Acting Studio II: Shakespeare
Credits: 5
Description: This acting studio centers around Shakespeare and specific techniques used in performing his plays. Continues concentrated work on basic acting skills and textual analysis through scene study. THEA 21 and THEA 23 are recommended as preparation. Admission is by audition at the first class meeting.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 122 — Indian Performance: Rama, Siv:
Course: THEA 122 — Indian Performance: Rama, Siva, Krishna
Credits: 5
Description: Study of the classical theater and dance of India, with attention to performance practice, aesthetic theory, relationship to religious practice devoted to Rama, Siva, and Krishna, political implications and intercultural experimentation.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 123 — Acting and Shakespeare:
Course: THEA 123 — Acting and Shakespeare
Credits: 5
Description: Challenges of performing Shakespearean and Renaissance plays are explored through confronting the acting problems they pose. Attention to verse scansion, character analysis, and textual meaning. Strategies for enacting scenes and monologues are tested in class presentations.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 124 — Movement for Performers:
Course: THEA 124 — Movement for Performers
Credits: 5
Description: Awareness and extension of personal movement repertoire, through observation, movement experience, and exploration.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 126 — Acting Studio III:
Course: THEA 126 — Acting Studio III
Credits: 5
Description: Individual work on acting skills and problems, with emphasis on individual interpretation and scene work with other students. THEA 21 and THEA 124 are recommended as preparation. Admission is by audition at the first class meeting.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 126M — The Meisner Technique: A Pra:
Course: THEA 126M — The Meisner Technique: A Practical Exploration
Credits: 5
Description: An intensive immersion into the teaching techniques and actor-training originated by Sanford Meisner. Presents exercises and projects utilizing improvisation, physical activities, and, finally, memorized text. THEA 21 and THEA 124 are recommended as preparation. Admission is by audition at the first class meeting.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 128 — Choreographic Workshop:
Course: THEA 128 — Choreographic Workshop
Credits: 2
Description: Intensive upper-division choreographic workshop that begins from the key motifs of historical dance to develop original work. Dancers made available to the student choreographers. Concurrent enrollment in THEA 139 is required.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 131A — Dance Studio II: Asian or As:
Course: THEA 131A — Dance Studio II: Asian or Asian Diasporic Practice
Credits: 5
Description: Continues the study of an Asian or Asian diasporic dance theory and practice. Focuses on intermediate dance technique, refinement of performance expression, and creative ownership of material, alongside critical engagement with aesthetic, cultural, and/or historical context.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 131B — Dance Studio II: Ballet:
Course: THEA 131B — Dance Studio II: Ballet
Credits: 5
Description: Continued study of classical ballet theory and practice with progressions in barre, center, and across the floor exercises. Focus on contemporary ballet and critical dance studies. Emphasis on musicality, strength and coordination, and refinement in epaulement in adagio and allegro sequences. Attention to body alignment and maintaining the kinetic integrity of the body while moving through space.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 31B or by permission.
courses.THEA 131C — Dance Studio II: Advanced Co:
Course: THEA 131C — Dance Studio II: Advanced Contemporary Forms and Practices
Credits: 5
Description: Continued study of contemporary dance theory and practice. Focus on intermediate dance technique, individual and group movement invention, choreographic voice, and theatrical applications.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 31C or permission of instructor.
courses.THEA 131L — Advanced Latin American Soci:
Course: THEA 131L — Advanced Latin American Social Dances
Credits: 5
Description: In this advanced-level course, students continue building on their technical and historical study of two Afro-Latin social dances which they began learning in THEA 31L : Samba from Brazil, and Salsa from Cuba. Students continue learning about the common Afro-Indigenous roots and stylistic evolutions of these dances, including key threads that connect a wide range of people and practices across the Latin Diaspora. Students also continue learning about the complex origins of Samba and Salsa and how they arose out of histories of persecution, enslavement, migration, and a deep desire to hold onto tradition and celebrate life in the face of great injustice. Students attend off-campus community dance events, participate in weekly movement practice, lectures, reading and writing assignments, and keep an embodiment journal.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 31L , or by permission of instructor.
courses.THEA 131X — Advanced Contemporary Forms:

Credits: 6
Description: Global Seminar exploring movement and choreographic practices, situating students' personal experiences within their counterparts from around the world. Students travel to Paris and Lyon to participate in an international dance festival. Students co-create an original work prior to the departure date to be presented at the festival. Students lead a peer-to-peer class via movement practices, choreography, or improvisation. This course immerses dancers into advanced levels of contemporary dance practice, continuing the exploration that began in THEA 31C and 131C into more nuance, greater perceptual skills, and deeper access to dynamic range of motion.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 135 — Choreography I:
Course: THEA 135 — Choreography I
Credits: 5
Description: Students explore sources for movement; gain expressivity in a wide range of movement elements; work in ensemble and solos; and explore the use of scores to develop collaborative skills.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 36 or by permission of the instructor.
courses.THEA 136 — Choreography II:
Course: THEA 136 — Choreography II
Credits: 5

Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 137 — Studies in Performance (Dance:

Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 137A — Studies in Performance (Danc:
Course: THEA 137A — Studies in Performance (Dance): Asian
Credits: 5
Description: Studies in Asian or Asian diasporic dance theory and practice, taken in connection with performance in a major dance concert. Students are required to work on all aspects of the production. Students work with guest and faculty choreographers.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 31A or by permission of the instructor. Concurrent enrollment in THEA 131A is required.
courses.THEA 139 — Random: With a Purpose:
Course: THEA 139 — Random: With a Purpose
Credits: 5
Description: Participation in a student-choreographed and directed dance concert under faculty supervision. Rehearsals culminate in public performances. Auditions to be held on the first day of class.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 141 — Play Direction Studio I:
Course: THEA 141 — Play Direction Studio I
Credits: 5

courses.THEA 142 — Play Direction Studio II:
Course: THEA 142 — Play Direction Studio II
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive studio exploration of the art and craft of directing. Primary focus on text analysis, collaboration with designers, developing a point of view and visual/auditory language for the play, staging techniques, and communication techniques with actors.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 145R — From Hamlet to Hamilton: Per:
Course: THEA 145R — From Hamlet to Hamilton: Performing Rhythm and Rhyme in the Twenty-first Century

courses.THEA 154 — Shakespeare Santa Cruz: Writi:
Course: THEA 154 — Shakespeare Santa Cruz: Writing in Response to the Bard

Description: Uses writing to respond to Shakespeare Santa Cruz's summer productions. courses.THEA 155 — Shakespeare to Go:
Course: THEA 155 — Shakespeare to Go

courses.THEA 157 — Playwriting:

Description: Students are given the opportunity to write their own scripts and refine them as the result of class discussion and scenework with actors. Work is on specific problems involving such elements as the structuring of a plot or the development of character.

courses.THEA 158 — New Play Festival:
Course: THEA 158 — New Play Festival

This course is open to students with all levels of theatrical/performance experience. Playwrights and projects are selected on the basis of submissions made in the previous quarter.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 159 — Advanced Playwriting:

Credits: 5
Description: Advanced study, through writing practice, of craft elements in the construction of dramatic work for the stage. Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.THEA 160 — Dramatic Theories:
Course: THEA 160 — Dramatic Theories
Credits: 5
Description: An examination of the theories of acting and directing from the 19th century to our own time, starting with the classic theater and concentrating on the 20th-century debate centered in Stanislavski and Brecht, Grotowski, and Robert Wilson.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
courses.THEA 161 — Advanced Dramaturgy:
Course: THEA 161 — Advanced Dramaturgy
Credits: 5
Description: Teaches the art and science of dramaturgy. Dramaturgy refers to the accumulated techniques that all theatrical artists employ to determine the aesthetic architecture of a piece of dramatic literature; discover everything needed to transform the inert script into a living performance; and apply that knowledge in a way that makes sense to an audience. Prerequisite THEA 160 may be used to satisfy a theater arts minor requirement. THEA 160 is typically taken in junior year but may be taken earlier if a student feels ready and wants to be able to take THEA 161 earlier. Taking both classes best prepares students to undertake dramaturgical work on theatrical productions.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): THEA 160 .
courses.THEA 161A — Irish Theater:
Course: THEA 161A — Irish Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the idea of a National Theater in Ireland from its beginnings in the founding of the National Literary Society in 1892 to the current vitality of the contemporary Irish Theater.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161B — Black Women and Diasporic Th:
Course: THEA 161B — Black Women and Diasporic Theatrical Expression
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the landscape of playmaking, theatrical production, and interdisciplinary performance art by women in the African Diaspora/Black Women in the United States and beyond. Course includes close reading, analysis and discussion of play scripts, poetry, related theoretical and historical readings, film and theatrical/performance art presentations. Also includes exploration of individual student artistic practice. Themes explored include: Black women and feminism, ritual as performance, meditations on the lived experience(s), identities and cultural values of Black women in the diaspora. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. For enrollment details, please see the Class Notes section in the Schedule of Classes Class Search when the course is offered, or contact the instructor or the Theater Arts program for information.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161C — Theater and Drama of the Ren:
Course: THEA 161C — Theater and Drama of the Renaissance
Credits: 5
Description: Examines selected plays from the Renaissance (1580-1680, Italy, Spain, England, and France) from a theatrical viewpoint. Covers Renaissance theater buildings and related critical materials. (Formerly The Theater and Drama of Renaissance Europe.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161D — Asian Theater: An Anthropolo:
Course: THEA 161D — Asian Theater: An Anthropological Approach
Credits: 5
Description: Art serves simultaneously to educate its audience to the group's traditional values and to test new ideas. Indian, Indonesian, and Japanese forms are studied in relation to their cultural context. Through videotapes, lecture demonstrations, performances, and scenework, students explore the forms.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161E — Mass Performance:
Course: THEA 161E — Mass Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the phenomenon of mass performance--when thousand of people perform the same thing at the same time. From political festivals, such as those of the French Revolution, to flash mobs, and covering the 19th century craze of mass gymnastics as well as Olympic opening ceremonies, the course analyzes the ideas and techniques behind mass performance. Students sharpen their critical skills in analyzing performance by working with texts, videos, live performance, and archives.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161H — Shakespeare In Asia:
Course: THEA 161H — Shakespeare In Asia
Credits: 5
Description: Shakespeare takes life in Asian reinterpretations that revivify languishing genres, duck political censorship, and explore new theatrical worlds. Indian, Japanese, Chinese, and Southeast Asian Shakespeares (1868 to the present) are introduced via lecture, critical reading, videos, and scene work.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161M — Sexuality, Gender, Drama, an:
Course: THEA 161M — Sexuality, Gender, Drama, and Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Exploration and analysis of the interrelationships between gender, sexuality, and performance on stage and on the page. Topics include gender and homosexuality in the history of performance and dramatic literature, drag, queer Shakespeare, closet drama, same-sex performance conditions (e.g., Greece) vs. dual-gendered (e.g., Restoration England). Combines study of theoretical texts and script with analysis and practice.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161P — Theater in the Chicano Power:
Course: THEA 161P — Theater in the Chicano Power Movement
Credits: 5
Description: Covers the rise of Teatro Chicano as a cultural-political force within the 1960's Chicano Power Movement starting with founding playwriter Luis Valdez and El Teatro Campesino and covering Chicana/o playwrights inspired by the movement, e.g. Cherrie Moraga, Luis Alfaro, and Josefina Lopez.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161Q — Queer Theatricks: Representa:
Course: THEA 161Q — Queer Theatricks: Representations and Sensibilities
Credits: 5
Description: An examination of the idea, form, and significance of queer/gay sensibility and representation in the English-speaking theater from the Renaissance to the present.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161R — Theatre of American Cultures:
Course: THEA 161R — Theatre of American Cultures: Fighting Oppression
Credits: 5
Description: Course uses theory and practice to explore Theater of the Oppressed (T.O.), a humanist theatrical form with its roots in social justice that breaks the boundary between audience and stage. Through audience participation as "spect-actors" everyone is invited to move from passive to active to imagine and embody social change. Led by jokers, who "difficultate" rather than "facilitate," T.O. has been used by groups around the world to explore, understand, and fight back against a wide range of oppressions. Students practice the games, techniques, methodology, and practical application of this activist theater form, explore the oxymoron of a T.O. class at UCSC, and discover what is possible when we become active creators of knowledge through theater. (Formerly Theater of American Cultures.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161S — American Drama: Politics and:
Course: THEA 161S — American Drama: Politics and Theater
Credits: 5

Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161T — Women in Theater:
Course: THEA 161T — Women in Theater
Credits: 5
Description: Explores female playwrights from textual, historical, and multicultural perspectives. Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161U — Performance of Story in Thea:
Course: THEA 161U — Performance of Story in Theater and Film
Credits: 5
Description: Examination of theory and practice of theater and film comparing and contrasting works having been adapted from one genre to another. Lecture, film, and video viewing. Discussions of materialist, psychoanalytic, and feminist approaches shared. Students cannot receive credit for this course and THEA 80X .
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161X — Experimental Performance:
Course: THEA 161X — Experimental Performance
Credits: 5
Description: Investigates the world of experimental performance, sharpening critical skills in reading texts, videos, live performance, and archives. The focus will be on modes of performance that broke with their contemporary norms, including dance, theater, puppetry, and other gatherings.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 161Y — Modern Ancient Drama:
Course: THEA 161Y — Modern Ancient Drama
Credits: 5
Description: Studies 20th- and 21st-century productions and adaptations of ancient Greek and Roman drama in theater, dance, music, and film, including Stravinsky, Graham, Pasolini, and Taymor. Discusses artists' goals, the sociopolitical context, ideas of authenticity and audience response.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.THEA 163A — Shakespeare:
Course: THEA 163A — Shakespeare
Credits: 5

courses.THEA 163E — Chekhov and His Impact:
Course: THEA 163E — Chekhov and His Impact

courses.THEA 163G — Special Studies in Playwrigh:

courses.THEA 163H — Henrik Ibsen and His Impact::

courses.THEA 163K — Special Studies in Playwrigh:
Course: THEA 163K — Special Studies in Playwrights: Euripides

Description: Examines the works of the classical Athenian tragedian Euripides. The class undertakes a thorough consideration of the playwright's plays in cultural, historical, theatrical, and literary context.

courses.THEA 164 — Issues in Dance History and T:

courses.THEA 165 — Dance Modernism:

Discussions may be supplemented by a movement practice component.

courses.THEA 166 — Ballet: A History:
Course: THEA 166 — Ballet: A History
Credits: 5
Description: Chronological critical and historical overview of ballet as a form of ethnic dance from its European origins to the present. Focus is on development of form in Americas and Asia as it crossed with other socio-culturally constructed categories such as race, gender, class, and sexual orientation. Discussions may be supplemented by a movement practice component.

courses.THEA 167 — Africanist Aesthetics: Live D:
Course: THEA 167 — Africanist Aesthetics: Live Dialogues in the Americas and Africa

courses.THEA 293 — Performance Research Project:

courses.THEA 295 — Group Critique:
Course: THEA 295 — Group Critique
Credits: 5
Description: Peer review and constructive assessment of works in progress. Students are required to give individual presentations to the group at least once a quarter. Educational objectives are to develop the ability to articulate themes and ideas in student's body of work; to strengthen critical skills in making, evaluating, and discussing theater art; to explore the role of the audience in context and criticism; and to investigate the ways artists construct, use, and maintain support communities.

courses.ARTG 143 — Ecofutures:
Course: ARTG 143 — Ecofutures
Credits: 5
Description: Students study the fields of ecofeminist art, climate fiction, virtual environmental art, Afrofuturism, Latinx futurism and Indigenous futurism, and create digital art relevant to these fields. The dual global crises of climate change and COVID-19 have forced a reevaluation of the idea of the human through a confrontation with the realities and histories of global colonialism and white supremacy. In response, social movements and artists have created artistic strategies which can envision futures beyond the horizon of the imagination of capitalism.
Requirements: Requirements Enrollment is restricted to senior Art and Design: Games and Playable Media majors.
